metadata.titleEn: S receiver functions of the Northeastern Tibetan Plateau (2009-2016)
metadata.description:
The dataset partially used in the study of paper 2018GC007986 includes S receiver functions derived from 48 permanent stations and 11 stations of a temporary HY array deployed in the northeastern Tibetan Plateau.
The dataset as a zipped file contains one folder, two files including NETibet_SRF.QBN and NETibet_SRF.QHD.
A spiking deconvolution in the time domain is used to calculate the P and S receiver functions, all the S receiver functions have been visually inspected to remove the bad traces that obviously different from the majority.
The dataset is applied to explore the lithospheric structure and understand the mechanism of northeastern expansion and growth of NE Tibetan Plateau.
metadata.instructions: Data folder is named as NETibet_SRF, where NETibet means the northeastern Tibetan Plateau and SRF denotes S receiver functions. Data format is Q-files format which can be processed with the help of Seismic Handler (SH) software.

authorList.unitEn: Institute of Tibetan Plateau Research, CAS

literatureList.titleEn: Seismic evidence for lateral asthenospheric flow beneath the northeastern Tibetan Plateau derived from S receiver functions
literatureList.referenceEn: Xu, Q., Pei, S.P., Yuan, X.H., Zhao, J.M., Liu, H.B., Tu, H.W., &Chen, S.Z. (2019). Seismic evidence for lateral asthenospheric flow beneath the northeastern Tibetan Plateau derived from S receiver functions. Geochemistry Geophysics Geosystems, 20(2), 883-894.

background: The northeastern (NE) Tibetan Plateau comprises the Songpan‐Ganzi terrane (SPGZ), the Qaidam‐Kunlun‐West Qinling terrane (QKW), and the Qilian terrane (QL), which are divided by the Kunlun fault (KLF), the South Qilian suture (SQS)‐West Qinling fault (WQL), and the North Qilian fault (NQF)‐Haiyuan fault (HY)‐Liupanshan fault (LPS), respectively. Changes in locations, ages, and styles of fault deformation suggest that the rate of deformation of the NE Tibetan Plateau has accelerated and that the orientation of crustal shortening has changed from NNE‐SSW to NE‐SW or ENE‐WSW since 20–15 Ma. Seismic reflection analysis, combined with other structural studies, reveals that the region of the NE Tibetan Plateau between the Kunlun fault and the Hexi Corridor (HC) has absorbed more than 250–350 km of Cenozoic N‐S shortening. These structural features indicate that the NE Tibetan Plateau is located at the leading edge of the northeastward expansion of the Tibetan Plateau, driven by continuous convergence following the collision of India and Eurasia. However, the modes of lithospheric deformation and their connections to the northeastern expansion and growth of the NE Tibetan Plateau remain unresolved. The southward subduction of the Asian lithospheric mantle, acting in multiple stages with inclined interfaces or over a long distance at a shallow angle, has been proposed to address the growth of the NE Tibetan Plateau. However, several recent findings indicate that the Asian lithospheric mantle does not subduct beneath the NE Tibetan Plateau. Furthermore, seismic anisotropy observations agree well with the model of the vertically coherent deformation between the crust and lithospheric mantle of the NE Tibetan Plateau. Therefore, whether southward subduction of the Asian Plate is occurring beneath the NE Tibetan Plateau is still disputed. In contrast, an asthenospheric flow model has been proposed, arguing that asthenospheric materials flow eastward through a low‐velocity zone at depths of 125–200 km beneath the WQO.
research objective: In this study, we present high‐resolution structural images of the LAB beneath the NE Tibetan Plateau and surrounding tectonic provinces obtained by the S‐RF depth migration technique using waveforms from newly deployed stations together with other earlier experiments.
challenges: The selected reference model involved in the ray tracing technique can introduce errors in the depth estimates of subsurface discontinuities. The discrepancy in the synthetic tests is probably associated with the application of the more sophisticated spectral element method and inadequate data coverage.
methods: The calculation of the S‐RFs mainly includes coordinate rotation and deconvolution. The three‐component seismograms (Z‐N‐E) are rotated to the local ray coordinate system (P‐SV‐SH) using the back azimuth of and incidence angle. The P component is deconvolved from the SV component to generate the S‐RF. After deconvolution, the obtained S‐RF is normalized to the maximum amplitude of the spike on the SV component. We also reverse the time axis and amplitudes of the S‐RF to compare with those of the P‐RF. To further intuitively depict the lateral variations in the lithospheric structure, we need to construct depth sections using a common conversion point (CCP) stacking approach. In this method, each cross section is divided into grids, and each grid has a 2‐km horizontal step and a 2‐km vertical step. The Sp amplitudes of each S‐RF are backprojected to their spatial locations where conversions occur along the incoming raypath. The amplitudes of all grids that are perpendicular to the profile within a width of 150 km are stacked along the designed profile to form the depth‐migrated section. Finally, we apply the horizontal stacking within one Fresnel zone to generate a smoothed image for further tectonic analysis. The S‐RFs for all the stations are obtained according to the methodology described above. We manually pick the high‐quality S‐RFs at each station using the following criteria: (1) We removed S‐RFs with unexpectedly large amplitudes or periodical oscillations compared with the stacked trace of all the S‐RFs and (2) we selected S‐RFs with clear Moho Sp phases appearing within ±1.5 s around the Moho Ps arrival time computed by the available crustal thickness and Vp/Vs ratio. Before further analysis, the retained S‐RFs are filtered with a low‐pass filter of 3 s. For both stations, we stack the moveout‐corrected S‐RFs (with a reference slowness of 6.4 s per degree) and estimate the uncertainties of the stack traces using bootstrapping analysis. We repeat 500 bootstrap realizations, which are performed by stacking the same number of S‐RFs that are randomly selected from the original S‐RFs, and then compute two standard deviations (2σ) to determine the typical values of the uncertainties in the sum trace at each station.
dataset: The teleseismic waveform data used in this study were recorded by 113 broadband stations, including 48 permanent stations in Gansu and Qianghai Provinces from the China National Seismic Network of China Earthquake Administration, which recorded data from January 2009 to December 2010, and 11 temporary stations of the HaiYuan array (HY), which were recently deployed by the Geophysical Group of the Institute of Tibetan Plateau Research, Chinese Academy of Sciences, from November 2014 to August 2016. The other 54 temporary stations were provided by the Incorporated Research Institutions for Seismology (IRIS), including 18 stations from the Gansu subarray of the ASCENT (X4) experiment, which was operated from January 2007 to December 2009, and 36 stations from the NETS array (ZV), which collected data from January 2008 to December 2010.
findings: Our migrated images indicate that the lithosphere‐asthenosphere boundary (LAB) lies at depths of 105–120 km beneath the Qilian terrane and reaches depths of 126–140 km below the Alxa and Ordos blocks. The most prominent variation in the LAB depth is the presence of LAB steps of no less than 20 km in the transition zone between the active NE Tibetan Plateau and the surrounding cratonic Alxa and Ordos blocks, which conflicts with the model of southward subduction of the Alxa and Ordos blocks. Therefore, we propose that these scenarios of LAB can be attributed to the delamination of fragmented mantle lithosphere in the transition zone between the NE Tibetan Plateau and the surrounding Alxa and Ordos blocks, triggered by lateral asthenospheric flow.

Verification.Question: Are there potential errors introduced in depth estimates due to the selected reference model in ray tracing technique?

Disjunctive.Question: Is the main data collection method used for analyzing lithospheric structures based on teleseismic waveform data, S-RF depth migration, or some other technique?
Are the challenges in accurately estimating subsurface discontinuities primarily due to the reference model in ray tracing, data coverage, or another factor?
Disjunctive.Answer: reference model in ray tracing and inadequate data coverage

Concept Completion.Question: What are the primary data collection methods used to gather teleseismic waveform data for analyzing lithospheric structure in the northeastern Tibetan Plateau?
When were the data from the broadband stations used in the S-wave receiver function study collected?
Concept Completion.Answer: January 2009 to December 2010, November 2014 to August 2016, January 2007 to December 2009, January 2008 to December 2010

Example.Question: Can you give an example of a data collection method used to obtain seismic waveforms for investigating lithospheric structures?
Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method is deploying broadband seismic stations, as seen with the 113 stations, including 48 permanent and 65 temporary stations, to collect teleseismic waveform data used for investigating lithospheric structures beneath the NE Tibetan Plateau.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced when estimating the depth of subsurface discontinuities using S-wave receiver functions?
Example.Answer: An example of a challenge is the potential errors introduced by the selected reference model in the ray tracing technique, which can affect the accuracy of depth estimates for subsurface discontinuities.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the specific attributes of teleseismic waveform data that are essential for generating high-resolution structural images?
Feature Specification.Answer: three-component seismograms, rotated to local ray coordinate systems, deconvolution techniques, S-wave receiver functions, amplitude comparisons, Moho Sp phase clarity, low-pass filter, stacking, bootstrapping analysis

Feature Specification.Question: What are the methodological challenges in using the S-RF depth migration technique for investigating lithospheric structures?
Feature Specification.Answer: potential for errors in depth estimates, discrepancies from sophisticated methods, inadequate data coverage

Quantification.Question: How many broadband stations were used to collect teleseismic waveform data in the northeast Tibetan Plateau research?
What is the range of depths at which the lithosphere‐asthenosphere boundary (LAB) was found beneath the Qilian terrane according to the findings?
How many temporary stations were deployed by the Geophysical Group of the Institute of Tibetan Plateau Research during their data collection period from 2014 to 2016?

Definition.Question: What is the 'S wave receiver function' technique used for in seismology?
Definition.Answer: The 'S wave receiver function' technique is used to calculate the S wave receiver functions from recorded teleseismic waveform data. This involves coordinate rotation and deconvolution of seismograms to reveal structural features like the lithosphere-asthenosphere boundary (LAB) beneath tectonic regions, as well as investigate the dynamics of lithospheric deformation.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods used for S-wave receiver functions compare to those used for other seismic reflection analyses in terms of accuracy and data resolution?
Comparison.Answer: The S-wave receiver function technique involves coordinate rotation and deconvolution of three-component seismograms to generate S-RFs, and constructs depth sections using a common conversion point stacking approach, which may differ from other seismic reflection analyses in terms of data resolution and accuracy. The selected reference model in ray tracing can introduce errors, suggesting that accuracy in S-wave receiver functions might be influenced by the complexity of the reference model and data coverage, compared to other seismic methods that might use different models and techniques.

Comparison.Question: What are the similarities and differences between the data collection challenges faced in the northeastern Tibetan Plateau and other tectonically active regions?
Comparison.Answer: In the northeastern Tibetan Plateau, challenges include potential errors in depth estimates due to the selected reference model in ray tracing and inadequate data coverage, which may be similar to challenges faced in other tectonically active regions where data sparsity or complex subsurface structures can also affect data collection. However, the specific geological and structural characteristics, like the presence of multiple fault lines and the debate on lithospheric deformation models, may present unique challenges in this region compared to others.

Interpretation.Question: What underlying rules or methodologies can be inferred from the process of manually selecting high-quality S-wave receiver functions for lithospheric studies?
Interpretation.Answer: The manual selection of high-quality S-wave receiver functions involves removing those with unexpectedly large amplitudes or periodical oscillations and ensuring clear Moho Sp phases appear within a specific timeframe. This suggests a rigorous approach to data quality control, highlighting the importance of precise phase identification in studying lithospheric structures.

Interpretation.Question: How do the challenges faced during depth estimation of subsurface discontinuities using ray tracing techniques reflect on the reliability of structural imaging in seismological studies?
Interpretation.Answer: The challenges such as errors introduced by the selected reference model in ray tracing techniques imply that structural imaging in seismological studies must account for potential discrepancies and errors. This highlights the need for sophisticated methods like spectral element methods and comprehensive data coverage to enhance accuracy.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes errors in the depth estimates of subsurface discontinuities when utilizing the S-RF depth migration technique?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The selected reference model involved in the ray tracing technique can introduce errors in the depth estimates of subsurface discontinuities. Additionally, discrepancies in synthetic tests are probably associated with the application of more sophisticated spectral element methods and inadequate data coverage.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why might certain S-RF records be discarded during the data collection process for investigating lithospheric structures?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: S-RF records might be discarded if they exhibit unexpectedly large amplitudes or periodical oscillations compared with the stacked trace of all the S-RFs. Records are also removed if they lack clear Moho Sp phases appearing within ±1.5 s around the Moho Ps arrival time, which is computed by the available crustal thickness and Vp/Vs ratio.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges in generating high-resolution structural images of the lithosphere-asthenosphere boundary (LAB) beneath the NE Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Challenges in generating high-resolution structural images of the LAB include the potential errors from the reference model used in ray tracing, discrepancies in synthetic tests due to more sophisticated spectral element methods, and inadequate data coverage, all of which can affect the accuracy of the depth estimates for subsurface discontinuities.

Causal Consequence.Question: What could be the consequences of integrating teleseismic waveform data from multiple temporary and permanent stations on the understanding of lithosphere-asthenosphere boundary variations in the NE Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating teleseismic waveform data from a combination of permanent and temporary stations allows for a more comprehensive spatial coverage and a higher resolution of structural imaging. This can lead to more precise delineation of the lithosphere-asthenosphere boundary and its variations, such as identifying LAB steps and understanding the lithospheric processes in transition zones influenced by asthenospheric flow in the NE Tibetan Plateau.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the goals of employing the S-wave receiver function (S-RF) depth migration technique in studying the lithosphere beneath tectonically active regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to present high-resolution structural images of the lithosphere-asthenosphere boundary (LAB) beneath the northeastern Tibetan Plateau and surrounding tectonic provinces. This aids in understanding the deep-seated processes driving the region's tectonic activity.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the objectives of visualizing and manually checking S-wave receiver function data in seismic research?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objective is to ensure the accuracy and reliability of the data by removing poor quality records that differ significantly from the majority. This step is crucial for obtaining precise structural insights and reducing the potential for errors in the interpretation of lithospheric features.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What specific techniques were employed to calculate the S-wave receiver functions from teleseismic waveform data in the context of analyzing the lithospheric structure?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The calculation of the S-wave receiver functions mainly includes coordinate rotation and deconvolution. The three-component seismograms (Z-N-E) are rotated to the local ray coordinate system (P-SV-SH) using the back azimuth and incidence angle. The P component is deconvolved from the SV component to generate the S-RF, which is then normalized to the maximum amplitude of the spike on the SV component. The time axis and amplitudes of the S-RF are reversed to compare with those of the P-RF.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How was the Common Conversion Point (CCP) stacking approach utilized to depict lateral variations in the lithospheric structure?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: In the CCP stacking approach, each cross section is divided into grids with a 2-km horizontal and vertical step. The Sp amplitudes of each S-RF are backprojected to their spatial locations where conversions occur along the incoming raypath. The amplitudes of all grids perpendicular to the profile within a width of 150 km are stacked along the designed profile to form the depth-migrated section, followed by horizontal stacking within one Fresnel zone to generate a smoothed image for tectonic analysis.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures were followed to ensure the quality and accuracy of the S-wave receiver functions used in the lithospheric study?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: High-quality S-RFs were manually selected at each station by removing those with unexpectedly large amplitudes or periodical oscillations compared with the stacked trace of all S-RFs. S-RFs with clear Moho Sp phases appearing within ±1.5 s around the Moho Ps arrival time were selected. A low-pass filter of 3 s was applied, and moveout-corrected S-RFs were stacked with a reference slowness of 6.4 s per degree. Uncertainties of the stack traces were estimated using bootstrapping analysis, involving 500 bootstrap realizations, to determine typical values of uncertainties.

Enablement.Question: What data collection methods enable the acquisition of high-resolution structural images of the lithosphere-asthenosphere boundary in complex tectonic regions?
Enablement.Answer: The data collection methods that enable this include recording teleseismic waveform data using a network of broadband stations, both permanent and temporary, and employing techniques such as S-wave receiver function (S-RF) depth migration. This approach utilizes waveforms from newly deployed and existing stations to achieve high-resolution structural imaging.

Enablement.Question: How does the use of a common conversion point (CCP) stacking approach enhance the interpretation of lithospheric structures in seismic studies?
Enablement.Answer: The CCP stacking approach enhances interpretation by allowing lateral variations in lithospheric structure to be depicted more intuitively. This method involves dividing each cross-section into grids and backprojecting Sp amplitudes of each S-RF to their spatial locations, then stacking these amplitudes to form a depth-migrated section, providing a clearer image for tectonic analysis.

Enablement.Question: What challenges in data collection and analysis might affect the accuracy of depth estimates of subsurface discontinuities in seismic studies?
Enablement.Answer: Challenges that might affect accuracy include errors introduced by the selected reference model in ray tracing techniques and discrepancies arising from the application of sophisticated methods like the spectral element method, as well as inadequate data coverage. These factors can lead to inaccuracies in estimating the depth of subsurface discontinuities.

Expectation.Question: Why might challenges arise in maintaining high accuracy when calculating S-wave receiver functions using pulse deconvolution methods?
Expectation.Answer: The selected reference model involved in the ray tracing technique can introduce errors in the depth estimates of subsurface discontinuities. Additionally, discrepancies in synthetic tests may be associated with the application of more sophisticated methods and inadequate data coverage.

Expectation.Question: Why could there be difficulties in utilizing pre-existing datasets from permanent and temporary stations to understand the lithospheric structure of the NE Tibetan Plateau?
Expectation.Answer: Difficulties could arise due to variations in data quality, coverage, and temporal scope. The discrepancies in the synthetic tests and the potential for errors introduced by the reference models used in ray tracing could further complicate the analysis.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential challenges in using the S-RF depth migration technique for imaging the lithosphere-asthenosphere boundary, and how might these challenges be addressed?
Judgmental.Answer: The potential challenges in using the S-RF depth migration technique include errors introduced by the selected reference model involved in the ray tracing technique, which can affect depth estimates of subsurface discontinuities. Additionally, inadequate data coverage and discrepancies associated with the application of more sophisticated spectral element methods can pose challenges. These issues might be addressed by improving data coverage and refining the reference models used in the ray tracing technique.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how the S-wave receiver functions are calculated and what specific techniques are used in the data collection process.
Assertion.Answer: The calculation of the S-wave receiver functions (S-RFs) involves coordinate rotation and deconvolution. Three-component seismograms (Z-N-E) are rotated to the local ray coordinate system (P-SV-SH) using the back azimuth and incidence angle. The P component is deconvolved from the SV component to generate the S-RF. The S-RF is then normalized, and the time axis and amplitudes are reversed for comparison with P-RFs. A common conversion point (CCP) stacking approach is used to construct depth sections, dividing each cross section into grids and projecting the Sp amplitudes of each S-RF to their spatial locations.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of the challenges involved in selecting reference models for ray tracing techniques in seismic studies.
Assertion.Answer: The selected reference model can introduce errors in the depth estimates of subsurface discontinuities. Discrepancies in synthetic tests might be associated with the application of more sophisticated methods like the spectral element method and inadequate data coverage, affecting the accuracy of the results.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the types of datasets that are incorporated in studies investigating the lithosphere-asthenosphere boundary (LAB) in tectonic regions.
Assertion.Answer: The datasets used include teleseismic waveform data recorded by 113 broadband stations, comprising 48 permanent stations from the China National Seismic Network and 11 temporary stations from the HaiYuan array, as well as 54 temporary stations from the Incorporated Research Institutions for Seismology (IRIS). These datasets are collected over different periods and are used to obtain high-resolution structural images of the LAB beneath tectonic regions.

Request/Directive.Question: Please provide an analysis of the challenges encountered in the data collection methods used for seismic waveform data in the northeastern Tibetan Plateau.
Request/Directive.Answer: The challenges include the potential errors introduced by the selected reference model in ray tracing, which can affect the depth estimates of subsurface discontinuities. Additionally, discrepancies in synthetic tests may arise due to the application of more sophisticated methods and inadequate data coverage.

Request/Directive.Question: Please provide a detailed examination of the methodologies used for constructing high-resolution structural images of the lithosphere-asthenosphere boundary in the northeastern Tibetan Plateau.
Request/Directive.Answer: The methodologies include using S-RF depth migration techniques with waveforms from newly deployed stations and previous experiments. This involves coordinate rotation, deconvolution, and constructing depth sections with a common conversion point stacking approach, ensuring precision through manual selection of high-quality S-RFs and filtering with a low-pass filter.
